titleStmt.title: An Update on Monitoring, Control, and Repair in Language Production

affiliation.orgName: Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences

analytic.title: An Update on Monitoring, Control, and Repair in Language Production

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Word production has traditionally been studied within two approaches, the psycholinguistic approach and the motor speech approach. In this paper, I will focus on how combining the strengths of these two approaches, as well as merging them with broader frameworks and theories of action and cognition, can guide language production research in novel directions. I will specifically focus on the three processes of monitoring, control, and error repair, which benefit most from interdisciplinary approaches. For monitoring, I will endorse a multi-process monitoring view with different roles for perceptual loop, forward models, and conflict monitoring. For control, I will argue for the learning view of cognitive control, which predicts domain-specificity in the application of control despite domain-generality in neural correlates of control. For repair, I will propose a new model, which combines the basic processes of psycholinguistic models with notions of post-selection processing and conflict-based monitoring and control, to arrive at an adaptive model of repairs in language production. Through these three specific proposals, I will demonstrate the necessity of a closer integration of learning and decision-making frameworks into models of word production, as an important general direction for future research.

div.p: Word production, monitoring, control, and repair

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Historically, word production has been studied within two approaches, the psycholinguistic approach and the motor speech approach [1][2][3] . Generally speaking, the focus of psycholinguistic models is mapping meaning to sound: How do speakers retrieve an arbitrary sound pattern (e.g., /kaet/) to refer to the furry pet? Motor speech models, on the other hand, focus on mapping sound patterns (e.g., /kaet/) to motor commands 3,4 . This difference in focus has caused the two approaches to remain largely separate. Moreover, with the exception of motor control research, which has heavily influenced motor speech models, neither approach has, traditionally, made close contact with more general theories of action and cognition.

Each approach has its own strengths. The main strength of the psycholinguistic approach is its broader view of language production as a process beyond a mere motor act. The emphasis of psycholinguistic models on semantic knowledge as the starting point of language production, naturally pushes these models to address key issues such as consequences of semantic similarity and mechanisms of competition and selection (how do I say cat, and not dog, when talking about the furry pet?). These issues, in turn, provide a natural bridge to theories of cognitive control and decision-making. Motor speech models, on the other hand, have two key advantages over the traditional psycholinguistic models of adult language production; they view the act of production as closely integrated with (a) monitoring and (b) learning. This close integration of production, monitoring and learning naturally leads to viewing the language production system as a goal-oriented, self-organizing system, which adjusts itself to different situations and task goals, similar to many other cognitive systems [5][6][7] .

My goal in the current paper is not to give a comprehensive overview of the models of word production, which exists elsewhere [8][9][10] , but rather to highlight what can be gained by considering both the psycholinguistic and motor speech approaches and linking them with more general theories of action and cognition. I will do so by focusing on mechanisms of monitoring, control, and repair in production. The discussion of these mechanisms will, in turn, bring out the critical role of learning and decision making in the production process. I will show that the resulting view offers new perspectives on current hotly debated issues, including the mechanisms underlying word selection and domain-generality/specificity of control processes that regulate language production.

div.head: Computational models of word production
div.p: To lay out the foundation for discussing monitoring, control, and repair processes that are the focus of this paper, I will briefly review the main models from the psycholinguistic and motor speech traditions, as well as one model that has attempted to merge the two. Within the psycholinguistic tradition, mapping meaning to sound entails at least two distinct stages 1 (Fig. 1a): mapping semantics to lexical items (lexical retrieval) and mapping lexical items to phonology (phonological encoding). The first step may also include morphological encoding for polymorphemic words, and is influenced by syntactic demands 1,3 . The second stage progresses into phonetic encoding and ultimately articulation. Two main computational models in the psycholinguistic tradition are Levelt et al. (1999) 3 and Dell (1986) 1 and their subsequent versions (see 8,10 for reviews). While details and scopes of the two models and their variants differ, they mostly agree on the core representations and the main stages of processing. Importantly, both models emphasize the co-activation of related representations within each layer of the production system (e.g., lexical item dog for the target cat; Fig. 1a). Modeling such coactivation and its consequences has been one of the major strengths of the psycholinguistic tradition, and has fostered a number of theories including competitive/non-competitive selections and domain-generality/specificity of cognitive control, which I will unpack in the following sections [11][12][13][14][15][16] . In addition, these models have been quite successful in explaining language impairment after brain damage or aphasia [17][18][19][20] , capturing the development of word production abilities in children 21,22 , and mapping language production processes onto brain regions [23][24][25][26] . Finally, psycholinguistic models can accommodate different modalities of language production, including written and typed production 27,28 . It is worth noting that despite their similarities, the two main psycholinguistic models differ in one key respect, namely, their assumption regarding modularity (see Box 1).

The main model from the motor speech tradition is Guenther's directions into velocities of articulators (DIVA) and its later version, gradient order DIVA or GODIVA 2,29,30 . The model is essentially a forward model of motor control (Fig. 1b). The starting point is the activation of a word in the speech sound map, which leads to a motor command (MT). Simultaneously, two other signals are issued to anticipate the perceptual consequences of this motor command in the auditory and somatosensory regions, called auditory target (AT) and somatosensory target (ST), respectively. Once the motor command has been executed, the controller compares these anticipated perceptual consequences to the actual ones and computes the error signal used for generating the corrective movements commands (ṀA, ṀS, and ṀFF), the sum of which (Ṁ) is used to adjust the motor movement of the vocal tracts. DIVA and its variants explain a wide range of findings in the acoustic-articulatory part of the language production system. These include learning to produce novel sounds and adjusting speech based on altered auditory or somatosensory 6 feedback, as well as disorders that affect sublexical representations, such as stuttering and apraxia of speech [31][32][33][34] . Moreover, these models have allowed for a detailed neural mapping of speech planning and execution processes to both cortical and subcortical regions 4,35,36 .

To date, no computational model has preserved the sophistication of GODIVA's account of articulation in a model that also addresses psycholinguistic issues, such as lexical access from meaning, but some models have incorporated elements from both. An example is Hickok's (2012) hierarchical state feedback control (HSFC) model 37 (Fig. 1c). The model is similar to DIVA in assuming that perception controls production, but changes the starting point from the speech sound map to the psycholinguistic concept of lemma 3 (the lexical item). The lemma hierarchically activates syllables and phonemes, each of which have their own perceptual control loops (auditory and proprioceptive, respectively). However, unlike DIVA, HSFC does not depend on overt consequences of action. Rather, lemma activation is hypothesized to activate both motor and perceptual representations, with the former suppressing the latter. A correct production of the target extinguishes the activation of the target's perceptual representation, but an error fails to do so, leading to the generation of an error signal. In proposing an internal check process independent of overt perceptual feedback, the model appeals to psycholinguistic notions such as "inner speech" 38 , while maintaining a core assumptions of motor speech theory, i.e., reliance of the speech production system on the perceptual system. However, the model does not implement the first stage of processing, i.e., semantic-to-lexical mapping.

As shown in this brief overview, psycholinguistic models pay much attention to coactivation of representations, while motor speech models highlight the interaction between perception and production systems. In the next section, I will review how this differential emphasis can be leveraged for monitoring and control of the language production system.

div.head: Monitoring
div.p: As noted earlier, one of the great strengths of motor speech models is that monitoring and control are integral to the production process. As seen in Fig. 1b and 1c, every act of production is accompanied by parallel activation of sensory representations that act as a "check" on production.
Psycholinguistic models, on the other hand, do not pose an integral monitoring mechanism.

Instead, for example, in Levelt et al.'s (1999) model, the language comprehension system is in charge of monitoring production. This account, called the "perceptual loop" 39 , is elegant in its assumption that speakers monitor their own speech the same way that they monitor others' speech 40 . However, data from individuals with aphasia show a dissociation between the ability to comprehend and the ability to monitor production 41,42 , which rules out the simple perceptual loop monitoring system. More recently, Roelofs (2020) 43 has redefined the perceptual loop as connections between representations in the production system and their corresponding representations in the perceptual system. This redefinition makes the perceptual loop account more similar to that of speech motor models.

Monitoring production through perception works well when production and perceptual representations are necessarily distinct. This is certainly true for the lower post-lexical aspects of production (articulatory-phonetic representations) and perception (acoustic representations), as these representations are clearly distinct and highly interactive, with changes to acoustic representations rapidly affecting production 44 . At higher layers of the production system, there is less motivation for, and evidence of, distinct production and perceptual representations. For example, it is unclear why there would be two sets of lemmas, one for perception and one for production, and even less clear why there would be two sets of semantic or syntactic features 45,46 .

Yet, those representations also need to be monitored and checked. Perhaps higher-level representations can only be monitored through the implementation of their sensory-motor representations? This idea implies that monitoring in very early stages of processing, before the activation of sensory-motor representations, is not possible. Moreover, monitoring ability should not really differ for errors arising during semantic-to-lexical mapping (e.g., cat → dog) and those arising during lexical-to-phonological mapping (e.g., cat → dat), as both will ultimately be monitored through the same sensory-motor representations. Both implications are unlikely to be true. EEG studies have revealed an early negativity (too early to be compatible with sensory-motor comparisons) in trials with a higher, compared to lower, error likelihood 47,48 . Also, both behavioral and neural evidence suggests differences in the detection of semantic vs. phonological/phonetic errors that arise during earlier vs. later stages of production [49][50][51] . It thus seems that speakers are equipped with a mechanism to detect the likelihood of an error early on, perhaps before it has even occurred. This is the idea behind the conflict monitoring account.

The conflict monitoring account 48,51,52 proposes that production errors are detected by assessing the level of conflict in the activation of competing representations. When one item is much more activated than others, conflict is low, and so is the probability of an error (Fig. 2). Conversely, when two or more items are highly coactivated, conflict is high, and errors are more likely.

Importantly, conflict monitoring can happen at any stage of production, and is not bound to sensory-motor representations. Also, it can be easily implemented in psycholinguistic activation models, which emphasize the coactivation of competing alternatives. While conflict monitoring has been considered a rival of the reinforcement learning account in explaining certain findings such as the such as the origin of error-related negativity 53 , the success of conflict monitoring is, in large part, owed to its predictive power over performance outcome, which is the focus of reinforcement learning. In other words, with experience, the production system learns to associate a certain outcome (errors) with higher conflict levels, and then uses high conflict as a signal for errors, establishing a close link between monitoring and learning. But what level of conflict should be considered "high"? Answering this question requires using a decision-making framework. Figure 2a shows the application of signal detection theory's (SDT) 54 framework to the distribution of conflict for correct and error trials. SDT's two parameters (d' for sensitivity and c for criterion) are perfectly interpretable in language production: d' depends on (a) the state of the production system and (b) nature of the task. Healthy mature production systems have a high d'. Damaged (e.g., post-stroke), immature (e.g., child), or lightly trained (e.g., L2 speakers) systems have lower d's 51,55,56 . This usually means that correct trials in these systems are also associated with higher amounts of conflict, making the two distributions less distinguishable. Criterion c depends on task goals 6 . If accuracy matters, c is set conservatively (low misses at the cost of higher false alarms).
If speed and fluency matter more, c is set liberally (low false alarms at the cost of higher misses).
False alarms, although uncommon, can be observed in individuals with aphasia as changing a correct response into an error 51,57 , and in neurotypical speakers, as disfluencies 58 .

The SDT framework applies equally well to the selection of the to-be-spoken word (SDT-type I) and to monitoring that selection (SDT-type II) 59 . For selection, the decision rule is: if conflict < c, then select; otherwise, wait (until conflict gets smaller with further spread of activation; Fig. 2b).

For monitoring, the decision rule is: if conflict < c, then pass as correct; otherwise, detect as an error. The selection and monitoring rules only differ in when they apply, with selection tending to occur earlier. In an ideal world, conflict monitoring would always operate before selection, preventing all errors. However, this could lead to silences and pauses that speakers may wish to avoid, leading them to sometimes commit to responding before checks are complete. This would manifest as overt errors needing detection and repair, although the rate of overt errors remains low in healthy mature systems 60 .

To summarize, applying SDT rules over distributions of conflict allows us to understand selection, monitoring, and error detection within the same framework. Two issues merit further discussion: the first issue is whether lexical selection is competitive or non-competitive; does selecting the word cat depend on how activated cat is per se, or how much more activated cat is compared to dog (Fig. 2b)? The second issue is the application of decision models other than SDT to language production. These two issues are discussed in Boxes 2 and 3, respectively.

There is an ongoing debate about which monitoring mechanism is the right one 43,61 . My own view is that language production is monitored through a combination of mechanisms. The original perceptual loop model assumes a conscious deliberate monitoring through the comprehension system 39 . This is certainly at work when we hear ourselves say the wrong word and realize the utterance did not make sense. In fact, the role of deliberate monitoring extends beyond listening to ourselves to include monitoring the audience for signs of incomprehension and actively using world knowledge and common ground to facilitate communication. Complementing these conscious processes are implicit mechanisms that have the advantage of being fast and effortless.

Forward models are excellent candidates for this purpose at the sublexical level, i.e., for the detection of phonological/phonetic errors or adjusting acoustic properties of speech [62][63][64][65][66] . Classic forward models like DIVA, however, monitor the overt consequences of behavior, precluding them from detection of potential errors. Moreover, speakers can detect errors in their silent, unarticulated inner speech, which has no overt perceptual consequences 38 . In these cases, detection mechanisms such as those proposed in HSFC or conflict monitoring provide a better explanation. Finally, models that hinge on sensory-motor interactions are not the best candidates for monitoring more abstract representations, while empirical evidence shows that such representations can indeed be monitored. Conflict monitoring proposes a solution for these cases. This multi-process monitoring view 61,67 finds support in empirical evidence, such as bimodal distribution of latencies related to error detection 68 and distinct neural signatures for errors detected with full and partial sensory feedback 69 . It is also compatible with computational models of error detection 70 , and is aligned with the well-known redundancies in monitoring other functions, such as gait 71 . Luckily, recent advances in the closer integration of monitoring processes with core production processes means that attempts to merge psycholinguistic and motor speech models will also bring together various monitoring mechanisms and nudge us closer to the implementation of the multi-process monitoring view.

Monitoring provides valuable information, but such information is only useful when it can be used to regulate the production system. This is generally known as "control". But when is control necessary and how is control implemented? I will answer these questions in the next section.

div.head: Control
div.p: Control is usually deemed necessary when performance suffers or is anticipated to suffer in the near future. One view assumes that, regardless of the underlying cause, the increased need for control will recruit the same control mechanism across tasks and domains. This is often called "domain-general" control and has been a popular view in both language and the broader cognitive literature [72][73][74][75][76] . In this section, I will assess the plausibility of the domain-general account of control in light of new theories of cognitive control and empirical evidence.

An increased need for control usually stems from increased competition from other representations 76,77 . Two distinct situations are possible: (a) cases where the stimulus-driven bottom-up information is sufficient to arrive at the correct response, and (b) cases where such information alone leads to the incorrect response. In language, the former case in akin to naming a picture (e.g., dog) after having named a similar picture (e.g., cat) [78][79][80][81] . Although the similarity creates interference (Box 2), the information provided by the current picture is aligned with the task goal of naming that picture. Compare this to Stroop-like tasks, where a prepotent response must be suppressed in favor of a less potent response, for example when for social reasons, one must produce a flattering word to describe a disliked object. Here, the stimulus-driven information would lead the speaker to utter a word that is incompatible with the task goal of being polite. Figure 3a shows an example of these two situations, implemented within an experimental paradigm with only two items per block 47,80 . In one condition, the task goal is to name the current picture, but the similarity between the current and the previous item creates behavioral interference (see Box 2).

In another condition, the task goal is to reverse the names of the two pictures (i.e., say cat when you see the dog and vice versa), creating a Stroop-like effect. While both situations can trigger the monitor to detect an increased need for control, there are both theoretical and empirical reasons to doubt that they recruit comparable control mechanisms.

Theoretically, the assumption of lateral inhibition (Box 2) is sufficient to achieve the goal when bottom-up information biases processing towards the correct response. In contrast, when bottomup information biases processing away from the correct response, lateral inhibition alone will not achieve the desired outcome ( Fig. 3a, red arrows mapping the stimulus to cat, which is the correct response in one task but not in the other). In the latter case, external control, usually from the prefrontal cortex (PFC) is required to bias processing based on the task goal 82 (Fig. 3a, blue arrows mapping stimulus to the goal-directed lexical representation). As can be seen in Figure 3a, the implementation of external control is essential for producing the correct response in one case, but not the other, pointing to possibly distinct control mechanisms in these two situations.

Empirical evidence is generally aligned with this theoretical position. Both situations activate medial PFC, such as the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), which is known to be involved in monitoring [83][84][85][86][87] , however, lateral PFC, which is often considered to implement control in collaboration with ACC, is consistently activated in Stroop-like tasks, but not in tasks that manipulate contextual similarity 86,88,89 . Further highlighting the differences in these control mechanisms are findings of distinct neural signature for Stroop-like and similarity-induced interference 47 . Moreover, behavioral evidence shows that the magnitude of similarity-induced interference in the semantic-lexical stage (e.g., cat/dog) does not correlate with similarity-induced interference in the lexical-segmental stage (e.g., cat/mat) 47,80,90 , pointing to local mechanism for resolving the interference induced by contextual similarity. On the other hand, the magnitude of interference induced by the need to override a prepotent response is correlated across conditions when two responses are semantically or phonologically related, pointing to a distinct mechanism for implementing this type of control 47,80 .

In short, task demands and their relation to stimulus-driven information determine whether lateral inhibition between local representations (e.g., middle and inferior temporal gyrus; MTG, ITG) for lexical representations 25,91,92 is sufficient to resolve the conflict or whether central control through the association cortex is required. This distinction does not mean that PFC cannot possibly be involved in implementing control in situations where bottom-up cues are sufficient. PFC can still help facilitate faster response generation by strengthening stimulus-response associations in such conditions 75,[93][94][95] , but this involvement is not necessary in the same way as in Stroop-like tasks.

The optional involvement of PFC for optimizing performance in such cases explains why PFC is sometimes implicated in tasks that manipulate semantic similarity, and sometimes not, whereas MTG and ITG are implicated much more consistently 86,89,92,96 .
But what about tasks that do require external control; are they controlled by a domain-general control mechanism? Here, I find it useful to define "domain-generality" more carefully 97,98 .

Domain-generality can have multiple facets. Evidence suggests that computational principles are often domain-general, as long as they are not inherently incompatible with the nature of certain representations 99 . Neural representations can also be domain-general, in the sense that they may carry out the same set of computations over representations in different domains. Association cortex is known for its capacity to do exactly that, for example, ventrolateral PFC is known to be involved in conflict resolution across different representations 74,[100][101][102][103][104] . Similarly, certain subcortical regions and their links to cortical areas have been proposed as candidates for the domain-generality of control 105 . The real question, however, is whether domain-generality in computations and neural correlates translates to domain-generality in application.

Domain-generality in application assumes that because the same population of neurons is involved in mediating control across two tasks, activating that population through increasing control demands in one task will lead to the better implementation of control in the other task 72,106 . An extension of this account through merging it with neuroplasticity 107 predicts that training control using one task should improve the implementation of control in other tasks 108,109 . Empirical evidence for domain-generality in application has been mixed, with some papers claiming transfer of control from one task to another, mostly in language comprehension 106,[110][111][112] , whereas the bulk of studies from the cognitive control literature point to task and domain-specific control 82,[113][114][115][116][117][118][119][120] .

Given the discrepancy in empirical findings, I believe we might benefit from approaching this question theoretically. Below, I will discuss the learning account of cognitive control and examine its predictions in lights of the current evidence.

div.head: The learning account of control
div.p: Before I explain the learning view, I will say a few words on what motivates the learning view of control. Recall that a major difference between the motor speech and psycholinguistic models is that the former is essentially a model of learning. This is important, because the model readily explains each act of production as an act of learning. Psycholinguistic models, on the other hand, do not pose such a tight link between production and learning. But much evidence suggests that they should. For example, several studies have shown that adult speakers rapidly and implicitly learn new phonotactic and orthotactic constraints embedded in strings of nonwords that they recite [121][122][123][124][125][126] (see 127 for a review). Integrating learning mechanisms into production also provides an elegant explanation for facilitation and interference effects of contextual similarity 14,128,129 as explained in Box 2. In short, a growing body of evidence suggests that action/production and learning are inseparable. This is the idea behind the learning account of control. Figures 3b and 3c contrast the traditional and learning views of cognitive control 82,130,131 . Note that both views accept the domain-generality of neural correlates of control 76,104 (red circles). However, they make opposite predictions regarding domain-generality in application. The traditional account assumes that the key element of control is the activation of the control region. Once activated through any task, this activation benefits any other task, regardless of overlap in task-specific representations 110,112 . In contrast, the learning view posits that the key element in control implementation is the strengthening of the connections between the control center and taskspecific representations. Since these connections are, by definition, task-specific, no benefit is expected for a new task. If anything, certain learning rules, such as error-based learning could even predict a disadvantage for the new task, as its connections to the control region could get weaker (i.e., reverse adaptation) 12 (see Box 2 for a parallel explanation of similarity-induced interference).

The learning account, similar to the traditional account, predicts within-task adaptation. This means that increased control demand in the current trial increases control implementation in the subsequent trials of the same task 132 . But the learning account makes two unique predictions: (a) since learning is, by definition, long-lasting, within-task adaptation should be resilient against the passage of time and intervening trials. (b) Recruitment of control for one task should lead to null or reverse cross-task adaptation in a different task. Both findings have empirical support in the cognitive control literature in general 82,133,134 and in language production, in specific 12,135 . It is worth noting that small positive cross-task adaptations 111,112 are not incompatible with the learning account, especially if mechanisms such as Hebbian learning are considered: at the end of a successful trial, all active mappings are reinforced. Therefore, if both sets of stimulus-response mappings across the two tasks and their connections to the control center are simultaneously activated, there is a possibility to observe small positive effects. However, this effect is expected to be inconsistent and weak, as it is usually not possible to keep the mappings of one task fully active while performing another task, hence the ubiquity of switch costs 136 . More importantly, uncovering small positive cross-task adaptation effects does not point to the kind of domaingenerality in application that would support brain training programs 97,137 .

div.head: Repair
div.p: A repair refers to the replacement of one response with another, e.g., "Please pass me the salt… I mean the pepper.". The mechanisms underlying linguistic repairs have remained largely obscured.

Given the close link between monitoring and repair, it is reasonable to expect that the early and late timelines of error detection will also be reflected in repairs, creating a bimodal distribution 68 .

Moreover, as discussed in the multi-process monitoring view, certain mechanisms are better suited for detecting certain types of errors, causing differences in detection and repair of semantic and phonological/phonetic errors 50,51,70 . But my goal in this section is to focus on a more fundamental issue: where do repairs come from and how do they replace the error? One possibility is that upon the detection of an error, the production process is started from scratch 138,139 . An alternative is some form of continued processing without a restart 56,140 .

The little empirical research that exists on the topic shows that at least some repairs can be extremely fast, with as little as 0 ms between stopping the production of the error and initiating the repair 141,142 . These rapid repairs support the view that repairs are the product of ongoing, rather than restarted processing. But there are two other intriguing findings that put additional constrains on the repair mechanism: (1) Repairs are seen in children as young as 2 years of age who are unable to consciously explain whether and why there was a repair 143,144 . Even in adults, repairs are not always accompanied by conscious awareness 145 . (2) Repairs do not seem to depend on accessing, or recognizing, the correct target. For example, an individual with aphasia produced a string of responses "apple, pineapple, pumpkin, orange, pineapple, peach?" in response to the target orange. As can be seen, non-target words (e.g., pineapple) were used as a repair and the target, when produced as the repair, was passed over without being recognized 56 . In short, repairs can be very fast, and largely independent of conscious comparison with a correct target. I will first propose a basic account that captures these properties. I will then augment this basic account with a conflict-based monitoring-control loop 146 , to propose an adaptive model of repairs that captures more elaborate findings. The current proposal focuses on lexical repairs (replacing one word with another word), but its general principles can be readily extended to cover other types of linguistic repairs as well.

div.head: The basic repair model
div.p: The basic model of repair is a time-based variant 147 conflict is, on average, higher. If a response is selected before the system has had time to resolve the conflict, the first selection may be an error (right panel). However, time often resolves conflict in favor of the correct response (see also Fig. 2b), making the second selection the correct response.

Repairs implemented through the respond-&-check process can be fast, because the repair has been processed all along 140 . They are also largely subconscious, because the check mechanism is the same implicit activation-based mechanism used for selection. Finally, they are independent of a standard correct response. For example, if the competition is between two or more representations, any one of them can get selected during the check process, regardless of its correctness, allowing the model to explain false alarms of the kind observed in individuals with aphasia, including the example given earlier in this section (see also 51 ).

div.head: The adaptive repair model
div.p: The basic model thus accounts for the three main properties of repairs. However, it has no mechanism to adapt to difficult situations. Current findings suggest that when the probability of an error increases, so does the probability of a repair 40,56 . This finding has the same flavor as within-task adaptation, discussed in the Control section. I will thus tackle this problem by situating the basic repair model in a monitoring-control loop triggered by conflict 146,147 . To recap, the adaptive repair model harnesses the basic dynamics of psycholinguistic models, combines it with conflict-based monitoring and control, and uses insights from the decisionmaking literature on threshold setting and post-response processing. Moreover, the model implements the notion of learning by computing a weighted average of conflict over many trials to be used as the regulating signal. This allows the model to amplify control in a more sustained manner, while also taking into account the transient, trial by trial, fluctuation in control needs 150 .

div.head: Conclusions and future directions
div.p: My goal in this paper was to combine insights from different traditions of language production research, as well as advances in other fields of cognition, to propose new directions for research on word production. I will summarize the conclusions in four points, together with their potential contribution to future directions. The first two points are focused on specifics mechanisms. The last two points are broader takeaways.

div.head: A multi-process monitoring view. Motor speech and psycholinguistic traditions differ in some
div.p: of the mechanisms they propose for monitoring and control of language production. These differences do not necessarily hint at a problem with one approach or the other. Rather, they likely reflect important differences in the nature of representations that are the focus of each tradition.
Therefore, instead of choosing the "right" monitoring mechanism, a more fruitful approach could be to view monitoring as a multi-mechanism process, with each mechanism best-suited to a certain

div.head: A repair mechanism embedded in the monitoring-control loop. The adaptive repair model,
div.p: proposed here, takes the idea of continued processing past the selection point and embeds it within the same conflict-driven monitoring-control loop that controls the primary production process.

This account is parsimonious, because control is always applied the same way, but depending on how quickly it takes effect it may either prevent an error or facilitate a repair. This model, however, is in its nascency. Many issues remain open to investigation such as the timeline of conflict monitoring during a trial, as well as the correct functions for weighting the recency of conflict and scaling of control.

div.head: Learning and production as one.
div.p: Unlike the psycholinguistic approach, the motor speech tradition views learning as a process integral to language production. For reasons stated in this paper, I believe that such integration plays a critical role in correctly understanding a range of behavioral findings from rapid adjustment to new constraints to facilitatory and inhibitory effects of contextual similarity, to control and repair processes. Fortunately, psycholinguistic models lend themselves well to the integration of learning mechanisms such as error-based and Hebbian learning. Future work should consider the power of learning accounts in explaining new phenomena, even when they do not fit the traditional definition of learning, e.g., similarity-driven behavioral interference 14,129 .

The implementation of learning mechanisms should not be restricted to the inner workings of the language production system, but should also extend to its interactions with other systems. A broader picture is emerging in the cognitive control literature pointing to the tight link between action and learning. An example is the learning view of cognitive control 130,131,151 . This view predicts that domain-generality in the neural underpinnings of control actually leads to domainspecificity in the application of control, and is supported by evidence from both language production and non-linguistic tasks. In my opinion, embracing the learning account of control and its application to language production is an excellent step towards answering more nuanced questions, such as how the parameters of such learning are set in different populations and under different circumstances.

div.head: Language production studied within a decision-making framework. Much of the discussion
div.p: in the current paper draws on principles and mechanisms from fields of cognition other than language. The successful application of such frameworks to studying language production encourages the continuation of this trend. One such framework is decision making. I have shown how applying SDT to distributions of conflict for correct and error responses can introduce useful concepts such as criterion setting into debates of selection and monitoring. Other decision making models have also been used and have advantages over SDT 152,153 . But there are also challenges in applying such models to the complex, non-linear process of word production 154 (Box 3). Resolving these challenges is only possible with a closer collaboration between language and decision scientists, but it is an effort with high payoff for both fields.

Finally, this piece, like any other perspective, does not claim to be complete. There are other emerging frameworks, such as the information-theoretic framework 155 , which offer unique tools and perspectives for studying language production. What is common between such frameworks and the current perspective is the use of theoretical knowledge gained in other fields to understand the process of language production.

div.head: Boxes Box 1. Is language production modular?
div.p: Modularity 156 refers to the encapsulation of information within each stage of processing.

Psycholinguistic models agree on the multi-stage nature of word processing, but they differ on the issue of modularity. This debate concerns two phenomena, cascading and interactivity. In a system with cascading, information from a higher layer leaks into lower layers, before the higher-level processing has been completed. In an interactive system, information that has cascaded to lower layers also feeds back to higher levels and influences processing in those layers. Levelt et al. (1999)'s model 3 does not allow cascading or interactivity and, consequently, is an example of a modular model, whereas Dell (1986) 1 is a prime example of an interactive model. Figure 1a shows both principles by showing the activation of various representational levels before the selection of the target lexical item (here, cat). Cascading is reflected in the activation of some of the phonology of the competing lexical items (e.g., /d/ for dog) 157 . Interactivity is shown in the activation of segmentally related lexical item (mat) through feedback from its segments 79,158,159 .

Several behavioral and neural findings now support non-modular models. For example, when participants named a picture as a couch, they were nevertheless faster at reading a following probe "soda", which was related to the alternative label sofa, compared to an unrelated word 157 . This finding shows cascading, because in order to prime "soda", participants must have activated the alternative label (sofa) down to at least its phonological representations, even though they obviously did not select it at the lexical level. Similarly, cascading between phonemes and articulatory-phonetic features was supported by the finding that segmental errors (e.g., /k/ → /g/) had a voice onset time somewhere between target and error phonemes, showing that the articulated product was a blend of the two phonemes 160 . Interactivity has also found support in a number of behavioral findings, including the mixed error effect 1 , the lexical bias effect 161 cf., 162 , and the repeated phoneme effect 1,27 . Neural data tell a similar story. Manipulating semantic similarity has effects on later processes, up to articulation, and manipulating segmental similarity affects earlier processes through feedback 47 .

Although the evidence cited above supports non-modular systems, they should not be taken as support against distinct processing stages 163 for two reasons. First, due to the mostly arbitrary mapping between semantic features and sounds of words, a single-stage mapping achieved by direct connections from individual semantic features to individual sounds is not possible. Also, even the behavioral and neural evidence that supports cascading and feedback points to a system that retains some modularity 47,164 . The modularity debate is not just of abstract theoretical interest 5 ; it has important consequences for the application of theoretical models to new data. For example, interpreting EEG components or fMRI activity as reflecting a specific process based on a timeline derived from a serial (modular) model 24,165 can be problematic, because such an approach neglects the fact that the current component/neural region is influenced by processing in layers before and after it (see 166 for a critical review of this approach and its problems).

div.head: Box 2. Is lexical selection competitive or not?
div.p: When we intend to say cat, does it matter how activated dog is? Much research has shown that increasing semantic similarity, especially taxonomic similarity (cat/dog), between a target and its context interferes with production 78,167,168 (see 166,169 for reviews). For decades, such interference was taken as evidence for competitive lexical selection 3,11,15,170 . The idea is that lexical selection can only proceed after a relative threshold, i.e., a minimum difference between the activation of target and competitor(s), has been reached (x in Fig. 2b). Opposing this idea, some researchers showed that production can be facilitated in semantically similar contexts, especially for thematic relations (bone/dog). This finding was taken as evidence for non-competitive lexical selection 13,171,172 . The idea here is that an item can be selected as soon as it passes an absolute threshold, without being affected by the activation of competing representations (see Fig. 2b).

Three points are noteworthy regarding this debate. First, while some computational models explicitly depend on competitive selection to explain interference and facilitation (e.g., 15 et passim), others do not 14,128,129 . Importantly, the latter type relies on incremental learning mechanisms to explain these effects 14,128,129,158,173 . One such mechanism is error-based learning 129 .

When cat is the target of production, its shared semantic features with dog also activate the word dog. At the end of production, error-based learning mechanisms strengthen the connections between the target (cat) and its semantic features, while simultaneously weakening the connections between the competitor (dog) and the features it shares with the target. This learning mechanism facilitates the retrieval of cat when it next becomes the target (i.e., repetition priming 174 ), but interferes with a subsequent production of dog. A similar mechanism can explain interference in segmentally related contexts 158,173 . Adopting the learning account has two advantages: (a) it explains the longevity of interference induced by contextual similarity 167,175 . (b) When combined with a more accurate representation of semantic relationships, it naturally accommodates the seemingly disparate facilitation and interference effects induced by thematic and taxonomic relations, respectively, which have been previously taken to imply mutually exclusive selection rules. Specifically, combining incremental learning mechanisms with the gradual activation of themes, captures thematic facilitation and taxonomical interference, irrespective of whether the model's selection rule is set to competitive or non-competitive 14 .

The second point worth noting is that the models that explain similarity-induced interference via learning do not necessarily deny the existence of mechanisms that impose some degree of competitive selection, such as lateral inhibition. In fact, given the prevalence of inhibitory interneurons and lateral inhibition in cognitive systems 176,177 , it would be strange to insist that the language production system is devoid of such connections. Acknowledging lateral inhibition naturally implies some competition in the system, which also motivates and constrains the use of measures such as conflict (i.e., conflict is not just measured between any two arbitrary representations, but between those with mutual inhibitory effects). However, the existence of lateral inhibition does not automatically endorse competitive selection accounts. It is theoretically possible to have lateral inhibition and still select a representation before lateral inhibition has driven down the competition below a fixed value of x (Fig. 2b), which brings me to point 3.

The third noteworthy point is that the debate assumes a dichotomy: Selection is either competitive or not. My own view is that such a binary view is incompatible with the workings of a highly adaptive goal-oriented system such as the language production 6,7 . Acknowledging the highly likely presence of lateral inhibition, I believe that the concept of a relative threshold x is useful, but this threshold can vary to ignore or highlight competition depending on situation and task goals 178 .

div.head: Box 3. Beyond SDT
div.p: While SDT provides a simple and useful framework for understanding the relationship between conflict, selection, and error detection, other kinds of decision models can also be applied to language data and have certain advantages over SDT. An example is evidence accumulation models (EAMs) 179,180 . Similar to SDT, they model choice based on evidence, but they also consider time, allowing evidence to accumulate gradually. The parameters of EAMs can be estimated through the quantitative fitting of choice-response time distributions. Similar to d' and c in SDT, EAM's drift rate and response threshold parameters are related to the quality of evidence, and the selection criterion, respectively. Mapped onto the lexical selection process, drift rate is akin to how quickly and strongly lexical items gain activation from semantic features. Response threshold is set by the selection rule. Given the close correspondence between EAM's parameters and dynamics of activation and selection, these models appear to be a good tool for examining the mechanisms of lexical selection. But which model is the right model for this purpose?

EAMs come in many different flavors. Some, like the linear ballistic accumulator (LBA) 181 and racing diffusion model (RDM) 182 , are inherently non-competitive, i.e., evidence for one choice is not evidence against another. In contrast, other variants such as the diffusion decision model (DDM) 183 are inherently competitive, with evidence for one choice always counting as evidence against the other. Fully competitive models like the DDM are often limited to binary choices (although extensions to multiple choices do exist 184 ), whereas accumulator and racing diffusion models more naturally accommodate multiple choices. At first glance, it appears that none of these models is well-suited for addressing the issues raised in the selection debate (Box 2): being limited to two choices is incompatible with the many linguistic choices faced by speakers, and utilizing models that naturally accommodate more choices means committing, a priori, to non-competitive selection.

However, while these models are sometimes used in their simplest form, they can also be used as building blocks for more complex models. For example, although LBA is not inherently competitive, competition can be introduced into the model in several ways. One such way is to set up the accumulators to represent relative information, e.g., the presence of one stimulus over another 185 . Another way is to build inhibitory connections between the accumulators 186 (see also leaky competing accumulator 187 ). The resulting models can capture competition effects without being restricted to two choices. Customized modeling of competition as inhibitory weights has an additional advantage: the inhibition parameter (i.e., the value(s) of the inhibitory weights) can vary freely and continuously. This continuity allows the model to go beyond a binary competitive/noncompetitive distinction, and capture graded competition effects, something that fully competitive models like the DDM cannot do. Such an approach is well-suited for investigating mechanisms of lexical selection and criterion setting, including the degree of competitiveness, its timeline during the evidence accumulation process 188 , and its possible fluctuations across individuals, conditions, and even trials.
Despite this clear promise, challenges remain in applying EAMs to language data. For example, EAMs usually require a large amount of data to generate stable and recoverable parameters.

Moreover, assumptions such as a constant rate of evidence accumulation within a trial, often made in the LBA, are probably too simplistic for the complex production process. Luckily, many such issues are also of great interest to decision scientists, and new solutions are being continuously investigated. For example, new Bayesian approaches allow for better fits and model-check routines with sparser data 189 , and a newer variant of LBA employs a non-stationary process of evidence accumulation 190 .

In short, EAMs are promising models for studying a range of issues related to selection, monitoring, and control in language production, however, their application to linguistic data can be complicated. This challenge can be overcome by a closer collaboration between language and decision scientists, and will likely benefit both fields.

figure.figDesc: of the Foygel and Dell's (2000) model 148 . In this time-based variant, activation dynamics are closer to evidence accumulation models (Box 3), i.e., they start from zero and grow over time with spreading activation, allowing for a more accurate representation of changes over time. Two ideas are behind the basic model. The first is the notion that conflict is generally higher in error vs. correct trials, discussed earlier in the Monitoring section. The second is the notion of continued processing past the point of response 48,149 . The basic repair model works by a simple respond-&-check mechanism. At time t, a response is made by selecting the most active representation, but processing continues a little longer, up to time t+1, when the system makes a second selection by the same rule. If the selected item matches the original selection, nothing is changed. If it does not, the second selection replaces the first one (an additional utility of post-processing is determining confidence in response 149 ).

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc: 4a shows this process. On correct trials (the majority of trials), conflict is consistently low throughout the trial (left panel), therefore, the selected item at the times of response and check is often the same (correct) response, leading to high confidence and no change. On error trials,

Figure 4bshows this adaptive model. The input activates the semantic features, and subsequently, lexical representations, where the respond-&-check mechanism is implemented. Conflict is continuously monitored at this level, providing the system with an average of conflict over all trials, weighted more heavily towards the most recent trial(s). If the average conflict around the time of the first selection (response) surpasses a certain threshold, control is recruited to boost the correct sematiclexical mapping for the second selection (check). The higher the conflict level, the larger the boost.This results in a higher proportion of repairs in more error-prone situations, compatible with the empirical findings147 .

type of representation. This view is more compatible with the behavioral and neural evidence pointing to differences in monitoring and repair of different kinds of errors. Moreover, multiple mechanisms may create useful redundancy, something that is characteristic of monitoring of other aspects of human behavior, such as gait control 71 . Embracing the multi-process monitoring view shifts the focus of future research to important open questions, such as the relative contribution of various mechanisms to monitoring different aspects of language production, or better ways of leveraging the complementary role of these mechanisms for rehabilitation after brain damage.

figure.head: AcknowledgmentsI
figure.figDesc: would like to thank Gary Dell and Jennifer Trueblood for helpful discussions and comments on an earlier version of this manuscript. This work was supported by NSF award BCS-2317121to N.N.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Models of word production. (a) Two-step interactive model 1 . Schematic of spreading activation for a trial with "cat" as the target. Red shows feedforward spreading activation and yellow shows feedback. For illustrative purposes only some phonetic features are shown. Similarly, feedback is only shown in part of the system but exists everywhere. (b) DIVA (adapted from 4 ). (c) Hierarchical state feedback control (adapted from 37 ).

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: The relationship between conflict and response selection. (a) Hypothetical distributions of conflict for correct and error trials, within the signal detection framework. d' reflects how cleanly separable the two distributions are. Criterion (c) can be put anywhere on the axis of conflict. Shifting c to the left makes behavior more conservative (fewer misses, more false alarms), whereas shifting c to the right makes behavior more liberal (fewer false alarms, more misses). (b) Change in conflict over time. A high-conflict trial can turn into a low-conflict trial over time (through spreading activation in neural networks or evidence accumulation in decision models). Conflict is inversely related to the difference between the activation of two (or more) items (x in the right-most figure). A competitive selection mechanism critically depends on reaching a certain value of x (a relative threshold). Non-competitive selection only needs an absolute threshold, irrespective of x (green).

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Control implementation. (a) Task-dependency of control. If bottom-up representations are sufficient to arrive at the correct response (left), recruitment of central control is optional, since control (blue arrows) will push processing in the same direction as bottom-up information (red arrow). Conversely, if bottom-up information is insufficient to arrive at the correct response (right) central control is necessary. (b) Traditional view and (c) Learning view of cognitive control (adapted from 130 ). Both accounts assume domain-generality in neural correlates of central control (red circles), but different mechanisms for control implementation, and therefore different predictions regarding domain-generality in application.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: The repair model. (a) The respond-&-check mechanism in the basic model for a correct trial (left) and an error trial (right). Reselection of the response in the former leads to high confidence and no additional action. In the latter, the changed outcome of selection triggers the replacement of the prior response with a repair. (b) The adaptive repair model. The basic repair process of respond-&-check is situated within a monitoring and control loop triggered by a weighted average of conflict.
